reviewText:
Ghost Master was the ultimate ghost game back in the year 2003 when it was first released. The ability to play as a ghost where you had to scare away people was a fun and unique experience, but somehow the idea hasnâ€™t been used in many other games after that one. The ones that did use it usually failed or were just mildly successful. So will Poltergeist A Pixelated Horror succeed where others have failed ? Letâ€™s take a closer look.

Poltergeist A Pixelated Horror (from now on referenced as Poltergeist if necessary) is at its heart a puzzle game and not a â€˜realâ€™ ghost simulator. You canâ€™t use your tricks and summons infinitely, thereâ€™s a limit to how many times you can perform a certain action. But before I get to this Iâ€™ll try to tell you a little bit more about the game itself.
After having lived in a mansion his entire life, Henry B. Knight (the main character of the game) eventually dies. Naturally, new people will start living in this mansion, but you canâ€™t and wonâ€™t accept this. In fact, you wonâ€™t be able to find peace until youâ€™ve scared them all away. So itâ€™s here that your quest to retake the mansion begins.
As you can clearly see Henry B. Knight is the star of the game. But you wonâ€™t actually see him all that often. Heâ€™ll sometimes appear as a â€˜special powerâ€™ ghost to scare away bosses, but other than that (and for some small cutscenes) you will hardly ever see him. This is weird but also acceptable since the game is played from an isometric perspective, also known as a birdâ€™s-eye view.
Each level has a couple of rooms tied together. In each room thereâ€™s usually at least one person or animal to be found, as well as some objects like TVâ€™s, beds and chairs. The exit can be located anywhere, it doesnâ€™t really matter, because once a person or animal is spooked he, she or it will automatically find their way towards this exit. The one thing you have to think about it is how to use the tools youâ€™re given to scare everyone away. Some of the levels will be easy and some of the later levels will absolutely challenge your mind. But fortunately you can always restart a level if things donâ€™t entirely go your way.
Each inhabitant has a meter that shows how easily one is spooked. A full meter (three circles) seems to be the limit but thereâ€™s also the possibility that a meter is black. This means you have to scare the person first before youâ€™re able to see how full their meter actually is.
There are quite a few ways to scare people; you have the basic tricks like moving objects and making noise or you can sometimes summon a ghost or a ghost that can take over people and walk around.
Iâ€™ve mentioned it before already, but since this is a puzzle game your objective is to use all of your available tools (or less, of course) to empty the rooms. Sometimes special characters (like exorcists and ghost hunters) will appear and these people have the ability to block one or more of your powers. In the beginning this is sometimes annoying, because if an action is blocked or stopped this means you usually have to restart the level. Later levels will allow you to finish it without having to use up all of your powers (if you play it strategically) making it a little bit more open and accessible.
Thereâ€™s no hint system so you have to figure things out all by yourself. This is sometimes a little harder than expected; Iâ€™ve played early levels that took me more than a few tries while I could finish other, later levels in one go.
Poltergeist uses multiple settings like the traditional (1800/1900â€™s) mansion but thereâ€™s also a modern setting and even an office to haunt. In total there are 60 levels; 15 for each setting with the last three levels being boss encounters. Iâ€™m not sure why there are even boss encounters;  the idea sounds cool, but the execution is very poor. Thatâ€™s because the boss fight levels are essentially the same as all the other levels, but the deal here is that the boss can only be scared away once all other inhabitants are gone. After that you can summon the ghost of Henry to scare him off. This last part is done with a simple mouseclick and thereâ€™s no real interaction. I think this couldâ€™ve used a little more thought. But other than that this is good fun.

Poltergeist isnâ€™t outstanding in its graphics department. In fact, its style is a bit of a coherent mess. I understand that itâ€™s probably because of financial and/or time constraints, but it uses both 2D sprites and 3D models. The sprites are okay but charmingly animated, but once the 3D models start to appear you get thrown out of the experience because â€“ to me â€“ it just doesnâ€™t look right. Or the other way around, Iâ€™m not sure. The textures on the other hand are very well done.
The interface is basic but gets the job done. A little more polish, a bit of resizing and maybe some extra color wouldâ€™ve been nice but itâ€™s good enough to understand what each icon does.
The music is perfect with haunting, Exorcist-like tunes. Itâ€™s done very well and complements the atmosphere, even though the game isnâ€™t about scary or creepy stuff (the setting, however, is). The frightened people, as well as their screams when they are running away, are realistic and believable. Thereâ€™s also nothing wrong with the sound effects; they might feel unnecessary at first but theyâ€™re essential to let the gamers know that something is actually happening. So every object and summon you use will make a sound.

Length wise thereâ€™s more than enough gameplay to keep you occupied for at least several hours. Each of the levels takes but a few minutes (if you know exactly what to do) so getting through the 60 levels will take you anywhere between 4-7 hours I think. I canâ€™t complain here, thereâ€™s more than enough to do.

Poltergeist might not become a classic like Ghost Master but despite that it has become an entertaining puzzle game worthy of my time. It doesnâ€™t bring anything new to the table but anyone looking for another ghost game, or just a good puzzle game in general, will absolutely have fun with this.

reviewText:
Pixels and ghosts is the theme here!

You play the role of a Poltergeist as they attempt to spook out the occupants of the house they built and died in. To do this you can use one of your spooky abilities to instil fear into the family members that have taken up residence in your home. However you're limited in the number of times you can use each ability per level, and some levels restrict which abilities are available... and this is where the puzzle element comes into the game.

You essentially have a limited number of moods to cause enough fear to get the people to leave. Some abilities cause more fear than other, while some people in the house can counter-act the spooky spells if they see them. For example the Gypsys and 'Good' witches will stop things from flying around if they're in the same room as the spell.

The game consists of 60 levels broken into Eras of 15 'puzzles' with 3 boss encounters before you can progress. Each Era has it's own theme, and 'topical' references. Each Era has it's own musical score too, and while that might sound a little grating as it's the only music you'll hear for 15 levels, I've yet to become overly annoyed by the music. In fact I've found it to have it's own strange level of charm, however I can understand it might not be for everyone.

Essentially Poltergeist: A Pixelated Horror is a puzzle game that requires a little bit of logic and understand to solve each level.

There might be those thinking this is similar to  'The Haunting' on the Mega Drive, sadly however this game doesn't have as much freedom in choices/design when it comes to clearing out the level or spooking the residents. Despite this it's still a fun experience, one I enjoyed playing in small bursts when I had a bit of downtime or was idly watching TV.

In short a fun puzzle game to play in short blasts. For a real treat click the Rubix Cube on Level 21 a few times (may cause a bug).

reviewText:
VIDEO REVIEW OF THE GAME
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=wOhVBu2niI8

Poltergeist: A Pixelated Horror is the latest game by indie developer Glitchy Pixel, and it's available for PC, Mac, Linux and Playstation Vita.

In the game you play as the ghost of Henry B. Knight and, as explained by the beginning cutscene, he doesn't want to lose his house as he had lost his wife and they first bought it.

The game takes place in several time periods, from the nineteenth century and the eighties, to our times. The differences are seen through the looks of the people inhabiting the mansion and the furniture that you'll be using to scare them away.

This game is essentially a puzzle game: you have a limited set of abilities that you must use to scare the people out of the mansion. There are three types of characters: normal characters (like people and animals), special characters (like witches and Ghostbusters) and bosses. The special characters are able to stop some of your abilities, while bosses can stop all of them. There are a total of 60 levels, and they get harder and harder as you progress through the game.

The graphics are really simple but charming, mixing pixelated characters with 3d objects. There are, however, multiple physics problems that are more funny than annoying.

The music is okay, and there is one track for each era.

Overall, this is a short casual game featuring apparitions, ghostbusters and lot of frustration. Recommended to puzzle game lovers.

reviewText:
So this game had an odd charm with it's graphics and gameplay but just to get it out of the way it's not worth the $8 they charge regularly.

Pros:

Charming gameplay and graphics

Interesting powers and enemies (some characters can block your abilities)

Cons:
Too expensive for how short it is (60 levels)

After you beat all 60 you unlock time trial but it's just the same levels again with a timer, it's only purpose seems to be to get the achievement for doing it under 90 mins.

Wish it let you scroll back so you could see more of the rooms.

Buggy especially the noise ability that moves people to different rooms, it's so inconsistant with who it calls to the room making it annoying in some puzzles. It prioritizes special enemies and bosses but I've had which special enemy it call change from one round to the other, I've also had bosses ignore it while regular dudes move. Also I've had possessed people respond to it so they don't run away after the possession wears off, sometimes the phantom guy will stay around after it's ended, other stuff... they're not horribly gamebreaking but they are annoying.

Sometimes the special enemies block so many abilities that it becomes obvious which abilities you need to use to get rid of them and it actually makes the puzzles easier. There are some puzzles you need to think a bit for but they're generally pretty easy. It's an interesting game and worth a look if you can get it for at least 50% off but at full prices just watch some walkthrough on youtube or something.
